opportunity of testing these views. The result of an <s>observation<\s> examination
of that district, fully bears out Mr. Darwin’s
opinion: where the two Formations come together the <s>two<\s> Cleavage
& Foliation are not only conformable at the
junction, but combine to<s>gether<\s> form an arch
in common. I have selected four sections to
illustrate this conformity under different circum-
stances: at Dunkeld, and on the east side of Loch
Lomond, fig. 1 & 3, an arch formed principally of the
foliation of the Mica Schist, is completed by
the addition of the cleavage of part of the Slate
on its southern flank. In Strath Earn & the
lower part of Glen Shee, Fig 4 & 5, the foliation
of the Mica Schist besides forming a complete
arch, supplies part of <s>another<\s> the imperfect portion
of another arch to the south, in which it is
combined conformably with the cleavage planes
of the Slates: a similar conformity between the foliation & cleavage is
found throughout but the stratification of the Slate, indicated
in the sections by the dotted lines, is unconformable
to the foliation of the Mica Schist<s>& may be [text?]<\s>  and is of no
account in the question under consideration.
* Not to encumber this paper with details foreign to its
principal object I reserve an account of the stratified rocks of
the Highland border for a communication to the Geological Society.
